awd_titl_txt: IAI Professional Development Seminars to develop capacity building for global environmental change science and its policy application in the Americas
awd_abstract_narration:
This award satisfies a U.S. Government contribution identified at the Twenty-first Meeting of the Inter-American Institute for Global Change Research, Conference of the Parties, whereby signatories of the Treaty Establishing the Inter-American Institute for Global Change Research (IAI) agreed to contributions towards a research budget supporting the activities of the IAI. Program Budget Support, for which this proposal is submitted, allows the Directorate of the IAI to provide support for a multidisciplinary, multinational research and capacity building program. The funds will be used to support five Professional Development Seminars (PDS) for global environmental challenges in the Americas. Seminars will explore: Transdisciplinary Scientific Team Management Skills; Managing Ecosystems Services from Tropical Forests; Ecohealth Approach for the Andean countries; Impacts of Global Change and Variability on Human Health in the MERCOSUR countries; and Building Resilience to Risk in Rural Areas. 

The intellectual merit of this proposal lies in the essential role of the IAI in developing research capacity in relation to the IAI's objectives to implement regional cooperation for interdisciplinary research on global environmental challenges; to conduct training of regional relevance which cannot be conducted by any single country or institution; to link research institutions of the region to global programs; to improve the scientific and technical capabilities and research infrastructure of the countries of the region; to foster standardization, collection, analysis and exchange of scientific data; and to provide scientific information to government towards public policy on global environmental challenges.

The IAI has been listed by the State Department as an international organization within the meaning of the Federal Employees International Organization Service Act, covered by 5 U.S.C. 3343 and 5 U.S.C. 3581.
Currently, the IAI Directorate is hosted by Uruguay on the campus of the Technological Laboratory of Uruguay in Montevideo where the IAI Directorate functions as an internationally recognized juridical personality, with the corresponding privileges and immunities granted by the Government of Uruguay.

por.por_cntn:
Addressing global challenges, such as climate change, diversity loss, and other complex science-policy global change issues of the 21st century demands novel capacity building programs and approaches that can effectively tackle these multifaceted problems. This grant contributed to the professional development of early-mid career scientists, policy and decision makers from the public and private sector, and other stakeholders with the skills, knowledge and tools to (1) form transdisciplinary teams and networks and work collaboratively, (2) work across disciplines, types of expertise (including non-scientific such as knowledge from indigenous peoples), and across sectors and geopolitical borders, (3) apply cutting-edge problem solving approaches, (4) science-policy communication, and (5) conduct science for policy advice and science diplomacy and decision making to address real world problems that are shared across the Americas.

From 2015 to 2023, the IAI carried out six Professional Development Seminars (PSD), Webinars, Courses and Fora addressing policy relevant global environmental change science themes and their applications. Activities emphasized the development of Transdisciplinary (TD) research teams, project proposals, and seed grants. 

Participants came from various areas of science, as well as policy, including environmental practitioners and other stakeholders from all 19 IAI member countries and non-member countries from the Americas (see IAI countries at www.iai.int). Regionally important themes were addressed: biodiversity and ecosystem services; land-use change and food and water security; climate, environment and health; governance, risk, vulnerability and adaptation, as well as TD research approaches, communication and engagement with policy and decision-makers. In addition, seed grants have been granted to some teams. They offer an opportunity for participants to stay engaged, to build networks and to apply the training provided to real-world issues. Moreover, the program has strengthened and fostered multinational and multidisciplinary collaboration, increasing the participation of small countries and a diversity of stakeholders in IAI research programs. Seed grants have been developed in collaboration with IAI and the Belmont Forum science programs so that current IAI capacity building and science programs enhance the training and generate cross-program interactions in addition to supporting opportunities for flexible funding mechanisms for scientists in the Americas.

The IAI’s approach involved several key components for capacity building. First, the program’s participants were exposed to innovative research methodologies, analytical tools, and concepts. This exposure complemented their disciplinary training and expertise and encouraged them towards more inter/transdisciplinary framings. Furthermore, participants received guidance in the development of professional teams and networks to provide them with the skills to work collaboratively and across disciplinary divides and geopolitical borders. In addition, teams were coached in established approaches that fostered a problem-orientation and the convergence of science, policy and application to address a real-world problem faced by a decision-maker/stakeholder. The mentorship provided participants with lessons learnt from established researchers and decision makers who have been working at the interface of science-policy-diplomacy and in interdisciplinary and transdisciplinary research.

More than 200 professionals from 19 IAI member countries participated in the activities of this grant, representing early to mid-career scientists, decision makers and representatives from the public and private sectors and civil society. 

Identification of solutions must be context-specific, based on the needs and priorities of LAC countries, and should encourage greater coordination, leadership, and communication. In this sense, eleven seed grants are being funded as a result of the activity on climate, environment and health (CEH). Despite its modest funding, the seed grant impact may be significant for research teams particularly from LAC. Projects addressed: Public health and institutional capacity (Guatemala and Argentina); Ayllu resilience and local knowledge (Bolivia); Climate, Health and agroecology (Uruguay, Argentina); Urban Heat Risk (Brazil, Ecuador, USA, Colombia, Chile ); Integrated FAIR Data Platform in the CEH Nexus (Argentina, Brazil, Chile, Uruguay); Community strategy for dengue (Argentina, Colombia, US), just to name a few.

In addition, there is great potential for policy outcomes, such as real engagement with stakeholders and decision makers in the public health sector, raising awareness and sharing of scientific knowledge, production of outreach materials and policy briefs for policy makers, climate and health data bases and methodologies for combining CEH information for public policy planning.

The IAI's innovative methods linking science-policy-diplomacy through training seminars with seed grants is a vanguard approach to provide early to mid-career scientists a novel way to use their science for the benefit of society, while they raise society’s awareness of the value of science in support of evidenced based decision making.

Another meaningful contribution of the training was the opportunity to experience the process of learning and practicing key elements for successful team building, co-design and framing of research questions between researchers from different areas of science the development of TD projects, and communicating and collaborating with decision-makers and other stakeholders from start to end, in addition to considerations of funding mechanisms and opportunities to support the TD research projects developed through the training events.
